awd_titl_txt: Systemic Risk and Mean Field Games
awd_abstract_narration:
The banking system can be viewed as a large network of agents in interaction, entering in contracts and exposed to the risk of counter-party defaults. Systemic risk corresponds to rare events of many defaults in cascade, disrupting liquidity and the economy as a whole. This research project concerns modeling this network in interaction and studying the limiting behavior as the number of agents becomes large. The project studies Nash equilibria, whose limits are described by so-called mean field games. The focus is on the effects of time delays and randomness on the network itself. This research aims to help understand and ultimately prevent the occurrence of systemic adverse events. From the point of view of the regulators, it is important to rank institutions according to their contributions to systemic risk; on the other hand, this ranking needs to be fair to the banks. The research also aims to develop mathematical tools to measure systemic risk and design fair allocation schemes.

Mathematically, systemic risk events in the network of banks correspond to a large deviation principle describing the occurrence of the small probability events in which a large number of participants are defaulting. The research consists in using mean field game theory to derive large deviation of the finite player games. The first goal is to consider the effect of delays in the game and develop the corresponding theory of mean field games with delay. The second goal is to study large deviations for games on stochastic networks. The main tool will be to use the master equation for the corresponding mean field game, specifically to explore how the stochastic nature of the network will affect the rate function in the large deviation principle. The third goal is to develop a duality approach to the systemic risk measures introduced in previous work, to ensure fairness of systemic risk allocations to the participants.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The research concerned three projects:

1. Mean Filed Games with Delay.

Mean field games which correspond to games between a large number of competitive agents and their Nash equilibria have attracted a lot of attention during the last 15 years. The PI and one of his PhD students introduced a delay feature in these games. Delays are a very important aspect in various practical models. The effect of this delay on the equlilibria have been studied. In particular the so-called master equation has been derived in presence of delay and a deep learning algorithm has been proposed to solve it. This algorithm has been widely cited and adapted to different situations.

2. Differential games between agents in chain interaction.

Mean filed interaction corresponds to all agent interactiong with all other agents, or, in other words, a fully coonected network of agents. In this part of the research, the PI and anther PhD student concentrated their effort to the opposite extreme type of networks, the chain interaction, where one agent interacts with another, which itself interacts with another, and so on... Nash equilibria have been identified and the differences with fully connected networks highlighted. A statistical test has been designed to decide in which type of interaction an agent is operating.

3. Systemic Risk Measures, Fairness, and Computation.

Systemic risk measures with scenario dependent allocations have been introduced by the PI and his collaborators. This part of the research consisted in studying the fairness of these systemic risk measures and the corresponding risk allocations. It has been shown that the resulting allocations were the output of an equiliibrium with risk exchange. Models with exponential utilities have been computed explicitely and served as benchmarks forn the theory as a well as the numerical methods. In particular, the PI with a PhD student have designed a deep learning method based on neural networks to computed systemic risk measures and their allocations. They have done so in the interesting case of mutidivariate systemic risk measures.

Results of the research on these three projects have been published in journal articles, conference proceedings, and book chapters. They have also been presented at a number of international conferences, workshops, and seminars.
